author: bridge-bot
content:
<SamWilsn> I'm not suggesting it needs to be the same here, but:

The litmus test we use for EIPs is whether two different _hypothetical_ implementations could exist and would need to coordinate on a particular topic.

In other words, we don't require that authors prove that there are two implementers ready to go. Authors just need to convince us that it's reasonable two groups _might_ implement a proposal.

author: bridge-bot
content:
<yoavw> The same applies to RIP, if for a different reason.  All RIPs are optional by definition, and in many cases one L2 will prioritize a feature and write an RIP for it while other L2s have different priorities and would implement the same one at a later time.  Therefore we don't require it to have two implementations, just to be relevant for more than one L2. (re @SamWilsn: I'm not suggesting it needs to be the same here, but:

The litmus test we use for EIPs is whether two different hypothetical implementations could exist and would need to coordinate on a particular topic.

In other words, we don't require that authors prove that there are two implementers ready to go. Authors just need to convince us that it's reasonable two groups might implement a proposal.)

author: bridge-bot
content: <SamWilsn> Perfect. Glad we're on the same page :3

author: bridge-bot
content: <iamchaals> As well as there being a clear theoretical case that two rollups would use something, I think it's good to have a *guideline* that we want more than one implementor who proposes something to say "yeah, we would be happy to implement it like that". Because we don't want 7 RIPs that propose 7 solutions to the same problem, each implementable in principle by all 7 proposers but in practice no two actually doing it in "the same way" (for values of "same" that don't mean sharing code, but do mean interoperable. Which has some implications for how to write the spec, too).

author: bridge-bot
content: <iamchaals> ("Guideline" != formal requirement that MUST be met in all cases)

author: spacemonkeyforta
content: Thanks <@550420431744794624> <@365300888354422794>! Makes sense. I'm also aware that Arbitrum for example has their own AIP process. If we wanted Arbitrum to integrate our precompile for example, would we go through the RIP process, the AIP process, or both?

author: hkalodner
content: For adoption on Arbitrum One you could either go directly to the AIP process or the RIP process first and then the AIP process second. This hasn't really been tested yet, but my guess would be that it'll be much easier to get changes through the AIP process if they've been adopted by the RIP process first

author: spacemonkeyforta
content: Thanks for the feedback. What I'm thinking through is the risk of going through the RIP process and not getting enough support vs. going straight to the AIP process.

author: bridge-bot
content: <yoavw> IMHO you have nothing to lose by making it an RIP. You'll have to make it an AIP in any case on Arbitrum, but making it an RIP an inviting other L2s to provide feedback before finalizing on Arbitrum will make future adoption on other chains easier, whereas if you only make it an AIP, you may have to make incompatible changes on other chains later.
